text.p: These are leading stories in this morning's Paris newspapers.
-- Foreign trade Minister Yves Galland explains in interview reform of public works contracts designed to simplify tenders and choice of suppliers and curtail bribery.
-- Bollore Technologies chairman Vincent Bollore reaffirms committment to keeping subsidiary Delmas despite rumours.
-- Over 50,000 people demonstrated in Brussels on Sunday against planned shut-down of a Renault assembly plant in Belgium.
-- Credit Mutuel chairman Etienne Pflimlin says in interview banks with a mutual status provide return on equity in line with other banks, and calls for a restructuring of the state-owned sector.
-- Credit Lyonnais earned 1.2 billion francs, pre-tax for 1996 on financial market activities.
-- Matra does not rule out a partnership with Cie des Signaux, Dasa or Aerospatiale ahead of bid for Thomson-CSF, which is being privatised.
-- State-owned insurer CNP seeks to sort out labour conflict this week. State recapitalisation not ruled out ahead of stock-exchange listing.
-- Caisse des Depots managing director Philippe Lagayette to continue modernisation process, seek some internationalisation.
-- European Renault workers unite for jobs.
-- EU refuses to send troops to Albania, approves small unit of advisers.
